articles.headline: Concerns Mount on Preparedness of Iraq’s Forces
articles.snippet: With American forces withdrawing, improvements in security may prove inadequate, officials said.
articles.abstract: With American forces withdrawing, improvements in security may prove inadequate, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s security forces, despite significant improvements, remain hobbled by shortages of men and equipment, by bureaucracy, corruption, political interference and security breaches that have resulted in the deaths of dozens of Iraqi and American troops already this year, according to officials from both countries.

articles.headline: Ailing Banks Need $75 Billion, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: After subjecting the biggest U.S. banks to stress tests, regulators ordered 10 to raise more capital and gave the rest clean bills of health.
articles.abstract: After subjecting the biggest U.S. banks to stress tests, regulators ordered 10 to raise more capital and gave the rest clean bills of health.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After subjecting the nation’s biggest banks to the most public scrutiny in decades, federal regulators ordered 10 of them on Thursday to raise a total of $75 billion in extra capital and gave the rest a clean bill of health.

articles.headline: Stress Test Results Split Financial Landscape
articles.snippet: The results gave a broad sense of the banking industry’s troubles and drew a line between strong and weak banks.
articles.abstract: The results gave a broad sense of the banking industry’s troubles and drew a line between strong and weak banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: At one bank in Alabama, the problem is a construction bust. At two in Ohio, the trouble is real estate. And in San Francisco, at Wells Fargo, the worry is credit cards — a staggering 26 percent of that bank’s card loans, federal regulators have concluded, might go bad if the economy takes a turn for the worse.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: The President’s Name Trips Up a Would-Be Voice of the News
articles.snippet: Amazon says it is fixing the Kindle’s computerized-voice feature, which had trouble with “Barack Obama.”
articles.abstract: Amazon says it is fixing the Kindle’s computerized-voice feature, which had trouble with “Barack Obama.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The Amazon Kindle, an electronic reader, has been lavished with praise by hopeful newspaper and book executives who say they believe it has the potential to do for newspapers and books what the iPod did for music.

articles.headline: GMAC, Among the Weakest, Seems in Line for a Bailout
articles.snippet: It looks as if one more bank — the onetime finance arm of General Motors — needs a bailout. And, four months ago, this bank was not even a bank.
articles.abstract: It looks as if one more bank — the onetime finance arm of General Motors — needs a bailout. And, four months ago, this bank was not even a bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: It looks as if one more bank needs a bailout. And, four months ago, this bank was not even a bank.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Findings, but No Final Word
articles.snippet: The numbers in the stress test report that are most impressive — perhaps shocking should be the word — are the estimates of possible losses from differing categories of assets.
articles.abstract: The numbers in the stress test report that are most impressive — perhaps shocking should be the word — are the estimates of possible losses from differing categories of assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that the stress tests are in, what do we really know about the health of the banking system?

articles.headline: Taxing Those With Insurance to Pay for Those Without
articles.snippet: The proposals being debated in Congress would start considering some part of the value of health benefits as income and tax it accordingly.
articles.abstract: The proposals being debated in Congress would start considering some part of the value of health benefits as income and tax it accordingly.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is an alluring way to pay for the ambitious plan to expand health coverage to the nearly 50 million people who are now uninsured. Simply put, the government would tax the people who already have the most expensive health benefits, as provided by their employers.

articles.headline: U.S. Jobless Rate Hits 8.9%, but Pace Eases
articles.snippet: The economy lost 539,000 jobs in April, a sign that the relentless pace of job losses was starting to level off.
articles.abstract: The economy lost 539,000 jobs in April, a sign that the relentless pace of job losses was starting to level off.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American job market remains dreadful and is still worsening, but at a slower pace than before  good news given the stomach-churning events of recent months. The government’s monthly employment report buoyed hopes that the longest, most punishing recession since the Great Depression may be relenting.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Jack Healy
